speaker: Doctor
text: How long have you been experiencing this neck swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been about 2 months now, I've noticed it's been getting bigger slowly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has the swelling changed in size or shape over the past few weeks?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been slowly increasing in size, I can feel it getting bigger when I run my hand over it.

speaker: Doctor
text: It's been about two months now. It started as a small lump, but lately, it's been growing and has changed shape a bit.

speaker: Patient
text: It's been getting a bit firmer to the touch, but I don't feel any pain when I press on it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or discomfort in the neck area, or is it more of a cosmetic concern for you?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I'd say it's more of a cosmetic concern for me, but I am a bit worried about it. I've been getting some strange looks from people at work, being a traffic warden, you know, I'm always interacting with people.

speaker: Doctor
text: There's been some pain, mostly when I turn my head to the left. It's been a dull ache, but it's been getting worse lately.

speaker: Patient
text: When I wake up in the morning, I can feel a bit of stiffness in that area, but it usually goes away after a few minutes of stretching.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any difficulty swallowing or breathing due to the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed anything like that. I can swallow and breathe normally, it's just the swelling that's bothering me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss recently, or changes in your appetite?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any changes in my appetite or weight recently. I've been eating normally, and my blood sugar levels have been stable since I've been taking my insulin and metformin regularly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any unusual sensations such as numbness or tingling in your arms or hands?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've been noticing some numbness in my left arm, particularly my fingers, when I'm golfing or playing tennis. It's not constant, but it happens when I'm exerting myself.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent infections, such as a sore throat or a cold, that could be contributing to the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any recent infections. I've been feeling pretty healthy overall, aside from this swelling on my neck.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous surgeries or injuries to the neck area that could be related to the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: I did have a colectomy when I was 43, it was due to colon cancer. I'm not sure if that's related to the swelling, but I thought I'd mention it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your voice, such as hoarseness or a raspy tone, since the swelling started?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my voice sounds fine, I don't think I've noticed any changes.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any swelling or lumps in other parts of your body, such as your lymph nodes or armpits?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any other swelling or lumps. Just this one on the nape of my neck, it's the only thing that's been bothering me.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical exam to get a better look at the swelling. Can you please sit up straight and tilt your head to the left for me, so I can see the swelling more clearly?

speaker: Patient
text: That's fine, I'll sit up straight and tilt my head to the left.

speaker: Doctor
text: As you tilt your head to the left, I can see the swelling is quite prominent. It appears to be fixed to the underlying tissue, which suggests it might be a solid mass. Can you tell me if you've had any history of thyroid problems or thyroid surgery in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I've never had any issues with my thyroid gland that I know of. I've had regular check-ups and blood tests over the years, and I don't think I've ever had any problems with it.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your physical exam, and it seems like the mass is indeed fixed to the underlying tissue. Can you tell me if you've had any radiation exposure or have been exposed to any substances that could potentially cause cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I don't think I've had any significant radiation exposure or been exposed to any known carcinogens. I've been working as a traffic warden for years, and I've never been around any hazardous materials. I do play golf regularly, but I'm not sure if that would be relevant.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your history of radiation exposure. Have you worked with any materials that could potentially cause thyroid cancer, such as uranium or thorium?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, I work outdoors most of the time, directing traffic. I'm not really exposed to any hazardous materials, just the usual traffic equipment and signs.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had a history of working with materials that could potentially cause thyroid cancer. That's concerning. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, or weight loss that could be related to an underlying condition?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I have been feeling a bit more fatigued lately, especially after my morning walks or when I'm playing golf. I've been attributing it to getting older, but now that you mention it, it might be something else.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any difficulty speaking or swallowing solid foods due to the swelling or pain in your neck?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I have had some trouble swallowing solid foods lately, especially when I eat dry bread or crackers. It's not a big issue, but I've noticed that it takes me a bit longer to swallow them than usual.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent travel or exposure to any areas known to have high levels of radiation or contaminated water?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't traveled anywhere recently, just the usual golf trips to the nearby courses.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Based on the symptoms and history you've provided, I have to say I'm concerned about the possibility of thyroid cancer. Given your history of radiation exposure and working with materials that could potentially cause cancer, I think we need to consider this a high-risk scenario. 

I'm going to order some further tests to confirm our suspicions. Can you please stay calm and let me get the necessary equipment to take some biopsies from the mass?
